Project Description  The Project is in Shandong Province, the northwestern part of 
which is in the Hai River Basin (HRB) that drains into Bohai Bay. 
The  Project  is  one  of  the  planned  wastewater  management 
projects under the national Hai River Basin Pollution Prevention 
and Control Plan. Shandong provincial government (SPG) issued 
its Shandong Hai River Basin (SHRB) Environmental Protection 
Plan in 2003. The proposed Project’s areas have been prioritized 
for implementation under the SHRB Plan. 
 
The  Project  includes  nine  subprojects  grouped  into  four 
components:  (i)  institutional  development,  (ii)  municipal 
wastewater management (MWM), (iii) solid waste management 
(SWM), and (iv) industrial wastewater management (IWM). The 
proposed  Project  will  be  implemented  in  secondary  cities  and 
counties  in  four  municipalities:  Binzhou,  Dezhou,  Jinan,  and 
Liaocheng. 
   
Rationale  With  the  lack  of  environmental  infrastructure,  particularly  in 
secondary cities and counties, and inadequate management of 
the  wastewater  and  solid  waste  services,  SPG  would  have 
difficulty achieving the pollution control targets in the SHRB Plan. 
The proposed Project will (i) support institutional changes and 
physical  investments  to  reduce  the  high  levels  of  untreated 
wastewater, (ii) adopt cleaner technologies, (iii) promote water 
reuse  to  augment  water  resources,  and  (iv)  control  non-point 
source of pollution through effective SWM. The Project is a major 
urban  infrastructure  initiative  under  Shandong’s  Tenth  5-Year 
Plan.

iv 
  The  Project  aims  to  address  the  key  sectoral  issues  and 
constraints by (i) employing an integrated multisector approach to 
environmental  pollution  control  in  SHRB;  (ii)  supporting 
institutional aspects  related  to  effective  environmental  pollution 
control  management  at  local  levels;  (iii)  addressing  water 
conservation  issues;  (iv)  enhancing  capacity  in  environmental 
pollution  control  through  improved  management  of  municipal, 
industrial  wastewater,  and  solid  waste  services;  and 
(v) development of sustainable wastewater treatment and SWM 
companies. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The impact of the Project is to improve the urban environment and 
public health in Shandong province by reducing pollution of the 
HRB from different sources. Major outcomes of the Project are to 
(i)  provide  improved  and  sustainable  wastewater  and  SWM 
services, on economically and environmentally sound principles 
and practices, through establishment of appropriate wastewater 
and solid waste utility companies in the project cities/counties; and 
(ii) implement an integrated approach for the management and 
control of solid waste, and municipal and industrial wastewater. In 
each project city/county, the service area will encompass most of 
the urbanized area, maximizing potential downstream benefits of 
improved  water  quality  through  point  and  non-point  source 
pollution control.

  Of the beneficiary population, 6.5% live below the local poverty 
line. The poverty and social analysis shows that the Project will 
contribute to (i) improved wastewater and solid waste facilities and 
services; (ii) reduced air, surface, and groundwater pollution; (iii) 
reduced  risks  of  exposure  to  disease  vectors;  (iv)  increased 
employment  opportunities  and  income-generating  activities;  (v) 
reduced risks of people falling into poverty due to closure of paper 
mills; and (vi) improved urban living environment and quality of 
life. An affordability analysis was undertaken of two representative 
household groups: the average-income group and the low-income 
group. The proposed tariffs will be set at levels that are affordable 
for  both  groups,  with  the  monthly  water  and  wastewater  bill 
accounting for 2.5% of the income of average family and 4.0% of 
that of the low-income households. The solid waste disposal bill 
will account for 0.4% of the income of the average family and 1% 
of that of the low-income family. For the poorest households, the 
city/county  governments  provide  a  minimum  living  standard 
scheme, which includes a provision for lifeline utility services. The 
county  and  city  governments  also  provide  a  rebate  on 
water/wastewater  bills  to  all  households  qualifying  for  social 
assistance  with  the  recent  increase  in  water  and  wastewater 
tariffs. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Potential  project  risks  involve  mainly  institutional  and  financial 
factors: (i) inadequate political support for institutional reform in 
SWM  and  MWM  sectors,  corporatization,  PSP  and  integration 
process;  unfamiliarity  with  performance-driven  commercial 
operations; and lack of staffing; (ii) resistance to required tariff-
setting  and  collection  mechanisms;  and  (iii)  low  user  fee 
collections  that  could  threaten  financial  sustainability. 
Comprehensive institutional development and training programs 
will be implemented in coordination with relevant departments to 
ensure support for the proper restructuring of SWM sector, and 
implementation of the agreed road map. The detailed tariff-setting 
and collection mechanisms and procedures will be developed in a 
participatory  way,  with  a  view  to  strengthening  the  regulatory 
functions  of  the  local  authorities.  Other  potential  risks  include 
weak  enforcement  of  separate  collection  of  hazardous  and 
municipal wastes, and pretreatment of industrial wastewater. The 
Project will address these risks by developing detailed guidelines 
for collection and reporting procedures, including (i) handling of 
hazardous waste; (ii) training for waste collectors to avoid mixed 
collection; (iii) spot checks and surveys around the landfill sites; 
and (iv) close collaboration with, and information-sharing among, 
local environmental protection bureaus.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) for the Shandong Hai River Basin Pollution Control Project 
(the Project). 
 
2.  The proposed Project is in Shandong Province, the northwestern part of which is in the Hai 
River Basin (HRB), which drains into Bohai Bay through nine tributaries.1 The Project is one of the 
planned wastewater management projects under the national Hai River Basin Pollution Prevention 
and  Control  Plan  (HRB  Plan),  funded  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB).2 Shandong 
provincial government (SPG) issued its Shandong HRB (SHRB) Environmental Protection Plan in 
2003. The proposed Project’s areas have been prioritized for implementation under the SHRB Plan. 
The project design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
3.  The pace of environmental pollution in the PRC has been increasing rapidly in step with the 
country’s swift economic growth over the past decade. Surface water and groundwater in particular 
have been affected, with water quality worsening in the major river basins of the PRC. Of the 
country’s seven major river basins, 52% of water bodies do not meet class III national quality 
standards.3 
 
4.  Increasing discharge of untreated or partially treated municipal and industrial wastewater is 
a direct and major cause of river pollution. Due to rapid economic growth, industrial wastewater 
comprises more than 70% of total wastewater generated in some cities. For example, the output 
from the paper industry, which is an important economic activity in Shandong and many other 
provinces,4 has grown more than tenfold in the past 2 decades. The industry is associated with 
significant environmental pollution.  
 
5.  In 2003, the PRC generated about 550 million tons of municipal solid waste. Approximately 
85% of it was disposed of in simple landfills or open dumps that do not meet acceptable sanitary 
requirements. In addition to direct adverse impacts on public health, the growing and uncontrolled 
disposal of solid waste contributes to increasing contamination of groundwater supplies through 
inadequate leachate collection systems.5 
 
6.  In its Tenth 5-year Plan (T5YP) (2001–2005), the Government focused on pollution control 
plans for the key river basins, including the HRB. This basin, which is about 265,000 square

7.  A severe water crisis in the densely populated HRB, especially in its southeastern areas, 
has resulted from a combination of (i) fast economic growth; (ii) overexploitation of surface and 
groundwater for domestic, industrial, and agricultural uses; and (iii) lack of adequate wastewater 
and solid waste treatment facilities. This situation has affected people’s lives and health seriously, 
and constrained local socioeconomic development and productivity. Major urban areas, including 
several megacities, have only partial wastewater treatment. More than 80% of the surface water 
and 50% of the groundwater are classified as polluted sources of raw water.  
 
8.  Shandong Province comprises 17 municipalities and 139 counties, districts, and cities, 
spread over 156,700 km2 with a population of 91.82 million. Shandong Province borders Hebei 
Province to the north, and faces Bohai Bay and the Yellow Sea to the east. Since 1990, provincial 
GDP has grown at more than 10% per year on average. Shandong accounted for about 11% of the 
national GDP in 2004.  
 
9.  The northwestern part of Shandong Province—the HRB portion—covers approximately 
26,000 km2 and includes four municipalities (Binzhou, Dezhou, Jinan, and Liaocheng) with 26 
counties and a population of 15.5 million. As in other parts of the HRB, groundwater overdraft and 
pollution are threatening the sustainable use of aquifers in Shandong. Monitoring records from 180 
water quality control sections in the SHRB show that most sections monitored are class V or worse, 
with a few sections rated class IV. Only one third of urban wastewater is being treated, and the rate 
of wastewater treatment and reuse is significantly lower. Solid waste infrastructure and sanitation 
services are deficient in most cities and counties in Shandong, putting public health at risk. 
 
10.  SHRB  consists  of  two  river  systems,  the  Zhang–Wei-Nan  and  the  Tuhai–Majia.  The 
proposed project areas are mainly in the Tuhai–Majia system, and include the Dehuixin, Majia, and 
Tuhai tributaries. Most sections in these rivers and tributaries are classified as worse than class V.  
 
11.  SPG recognizes the need to address environmental pollution. Investments in environmental 
infrastructure (water supply and sanitation, water conservation, and environmental management) in 
Shandong Province reportedly totaled about $3.2 billion over the past 4 years, which is equivalent 
to 2.6% of provincial GDP. Wastewater charges are being increased gradually to cover the full cost 
plus a reasonable profit margin to provide commercial incentives to invest in wastewater treatment 
facilities. However, to enhance the quality of urban life and ensure a sustainable foundation for 
economic growth in the entire SHRB, more investment and institutional reforms are required to 
address wastewater and solid waste pollution control.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
12.  Key problems and opportunities include (i) groundwater and surface water pollution in the 
SHRB, (ii) scarcity of good quality water resources, (iii) inadequate wastewater treatment capacity, 
(iv) lack of integrated management for industrial and municipal wastewaters, (v) inadequate solid 
waste management (SWM) facilities and services, (vi) need to enhance efficiency of industries 
through adoption of clean production technologies, and (vii) need to build operational efficiencies 
and managerial capacities of the utilities. 
 
13.  The HRB Plan. The Government recognizes that adequate environmental protection and 
pollution control are prerequisites for sustainable economic growth. The HRB has been identified

as one of three river basins and three lake basins in the PRC with the highest priority for improving 
water quality. The HRB Plan, an action program under the PRC’s Green Plan,7 sets pollution 
control targets for 2000 and 2010. The key parameters used for water quality planning are annual 
chemical oxygen demand (COD)8 and ammonia nitrogen loads.  
 
14.  The  Ministry  of  Construction,  through  the  provincial  and  municipal  construction 
commissions,  is  responsible  for  overseeing  urban  plans  for  major  cities,  including  plans  and 
investments  for  urban  wastewater  treatment  and  water  resources  protection.  The  State 
Environmental Protection Administration, through its policies and programs, plays an important role 
in the development of sound environmental practices in the PRC water sector.  
 
15.  The T5YP and ADB’s Country Strategy and Program9 for the PRC prioritize investments for 
improving  environmental  management,  water  conservation,  and  reducing  water  pollution.  The 
Government plans to (i) increase centralized urban wastewater treatment during the T5YP by 26 
million cubic meters (m3), (ii) raise the treatment rate of municipal wastewater from 34% to 45%, 
and (iii) increase the use of recycled water by industries from 50% in 2000 to 60% in 2005.  
Environmental protection continues to be important focus of the Government in the 11th 5-Year 
Plan (2006–2010). 
 
16.  The  SHRB  Plan  sets  the  standards  for  pollutant  discharges  from  water  sub-basins, 
including those from solid waste. Under this plan, all municipalities and counties are required to 
take the following actions on pollution control: (i) surface waters supplying raw water for urban use 
are required to meet class III; (ii) water quality in the main rivers and canals needs to improve 
before 2006, with target reductions in pollutant discharges of COD;10 (iii) 45% of urban wastewater 
must  receive  secondary  treatment;  (iv)  paper  mills  are  required  to  meet  industrial  discharge 
standards;11 and (v) solid waste pollution must be controlled, while construction of SWM facilities is 
accelerated. 
 
17.  Project Rationale. With the lack of environmental infrastructure, particularly in secondary 
cities and counties, and inadequate management of the wastewater and solid waste services, SPG 
would have difficulty achieving the pollution control targets in the SHRB Plan. The Project will (i) 
support institutional changes and physical investments to reduce the high levels of untreated

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
30.  The  impact  of  the  Project  is  to  improve  the  urban  environment  and  public  health  in 
Shandong Province by reducing pollution of the HRB from different sources. The Project involves (i) 
improving municipal wastewater collection, treatment, and reuse; (ii) providing municipal solid 
waste  collection  and  disposal;  (iii)  adopting  clean  industrial  processes  and  improving  waste 
management;  and  (iv)  supporting  the  institutional  development  of  utilities.  One  of  the  major 
outcomes  of  the  Project  is  improved  and  sustainable  wastewater  and  SWM  services  on 
economically  and  environmentally  sound  principles  and  practices.  Another  outcome  is  the 
implementation of an integrated approach for the management of municipal wastewater and solid 
waste  point  and  non-point  pollution  sources.  The  proposed  Project  will  be  implemented  in 
secondary cities and counties within four municipalities: Binzhou, Dezhou, Jinan, and Liaocheng.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
31.  The proposed Project has nine subprojects grouped into four components: (i) institutional 
development; (ii) MWM; (iii) SWM; and (iv) industrial wastewater management (IWM).  
 
32.  Institutional  Development.  This  component  aims  to  develop  financially  sustainable, 
operationally  efficient,  and  managerially  autonomous  utility  companies  in  MWM  and  SWM 
subprojects. These utilities would effectively manage project-created assets for efficient service 
delivery. The institutions responsible for implementing the four MWM and three SWM subprojects 
are at an early stage of development and need assistance in streamlining their processes. 
 
33.  The Shandong Project Management Office (SPMO), LPMOs, and IAs have agreed on a 
road map for institutional development under the Project, which includes a series of gradual steps 
for achieving the component’s objectives. Utility companies for each of the four MWM and three 
SWM  subprojects  will  be  established  and  registered  before  loan  negotiations.  Institutional 
consultants will work with the LPMOs and IAs to develop and implement the road map during loan 
implementation (Appendix 2).   
 
34.  Municipal Wastewater Management. This component has four subprojects in:  
 
(i)  Binzhou  City  (Economic  Development  Zone),  which  includes  40,000  ton  per  day  (t/d) 
capacity WWTP, 30,000 t/d reuse water treatment plant, approximately 65 kilometers (km)

(ii)  Gaotang County, which includes 40,000 t/d WWTP (phase II), 40,000 t/d reuse water

(iii)  Linqing City, which includes 100,000 t/d WWTP, 50,000 t/d reuse water treatment plant, 12 
km of trunk sewer, reuse water piping, and treatment effluent discharge lines;19 and  
(iv)  Shanghe County, which includes 40,000 t/d WWTP, 21 km of sewer, and two lift stations, 
with a 10,000 t/d and 30,000 t/d capacity, respectively.

residents’ quality of life and eliminate a major source of pollution in the future. Pollution reduction to 
HRB will be indirect, but with long-term effects.

(i)  Changyuan Paper Mill, including 1,800 m3/day black liquor20 recovery system with 200 t/d

C.  Special Features 
 
41.  The Project adopts a multisectoral approach to environmental pollution control, as well as 
integrated management of the chain from collection and treatment to reuse for MWM, SWM, and 
IWM (paras. 19–20). Special features are described below (paras. 42–48). 
 
42.  Use of Reclaimed Wastewater. This is a new frontier in the PRC. In Shandong Province 
the scarcity of water resources is inhibiting economic growth and undermining residents’ quality of 
life. The Project provides wastewater reclamation in three cities/counties and promotes industrial 
use of the reclaimed water, conserving good quality water for drinking or other domestic uses. 
 
43.   Pioneering  Institutional  Arrangements  for  SWM. The PRC has made considerable 
progress in MWM reforms, though SWM institutional reform is still at an early stage. Only a few 
cities, such as Hangzhou and Chongqing, have started SWM corporatization reform. The creation 
of  landfills  alone  will  not  address  sustainability  issues,  and  a  focus  on  management  and 
operational efficiencies is needed. Under the Project, transparent and efficient tariff-setting and 
collection mechanisms will be implemented. Corporatization will establish three state-owned SWM 
companies with autonomous management, operations, and financial systems. These changes will 
facilitate (i) the reflection of the true cost of all SWM services in tariffs; (ii) financial sustainability; (ii) 
PSP; and (iv) innovative processes, such as waste-to-energy (para. 44).

gas (GHG) emissions and promoting sustainable development (Appendix 3).

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
72.  Environmental  Benefits.  The  Project  will  contribute  to  pollution  control  in  the  HRB, 
particularly in the Tuhai–Majia River system. The multisector and multimedia approach to pollution 
prevention  in  the  HRB  will  provide  the  most  sustainable  prospects  for  reducing  waterborne 
pollution, achieving surface water quality targets, and improving living conditions in the project 
areas. 
 
73.  The improved wastewater collection and treatment systems will contribute to a significant 
reduction of COD (75%) and ammonia nitrogen (50%) in the receiving rivers, enabling each 
subproject area to attain the limits set by the T5YP. The industrial reuse of treated effluent will 
meet the need for water conservation facing the project areas.  
 
74.  Under the SWM component, improvement of collection, transport, and disposal will address 
the need to treat the growing volume of solid waste in an environmentally sound manner and 
reduce contamination of the urban environment. The new sanitary landfills with leachate collection 
will minimize the waste constituents discharge into the relevant aquifers, reducing groundwater 
contamination. The efficient collection of LFG with the use of CDM will reduce environmental

companies. This is a pioneering attempt in the SWM sector in the PRC, which is in line with the 
Government’s strategy to reduce its direct involvement in waste management. Key actions include 
(i)  legal  and  corporate  institutional  strengthening;  (ii)  strategic  planning  for  SWM  and  MWM

reduce the incidence of water- and vector-related diseases, and improve living conditions of the 
population. Based on project survey data of 1,200 respondents, health costs have been computed

monitoring the public health impact of the Project.

91.  Project Risks. Potential project risks relate mainly to institutional and financial factors: (i) 
inadequate political support for institutional reforms in SWM and MWM sectors, corporatization, 
and  integration  process;  resistance  to  change  to  commercial  operations;  and  lack  of  staffing 
resources;  (ii)  resistance  to  required  tariff  setting/collection  mechanisms;  (iii)  low  user  fee 
collections that threaten financial sustainability; and (iv) decline in private sector interest triggered 
by external factors. To mitigate these risks, a comprehensive institutional development program will 
be developed and implemented in coordination with all relevant departments to ensure support for 
the  proper  restructuring  of  SWM  sector.  Training  programs  for  the  new  companies  will  be 
developed under the Project. The detailed tariff-setting/collection mechanisms will be developed in 
a participatory way, with a view to strengthening the regulatory functions of the local authorities.   
 
92.  Another potential risk involves weak enforcement of separate collection of hazardous and 
municipal wastes, and pretreatment of industrial wastewater. Changes in design standards and 
environmental compliance requirements to be introduced in the 11th 5-Year Plan (2006–2010) 
could  pose  another  risk.  However,  these  risks  will  be  minimized  by  (i)  developing  detailed 
guidelines for collection and reporting procedures, including handling of hazardous wastes; (ii) 
training waste collectors to avoid mixed collection; (iii) implementing spot checks and surveys 
around landfill sites; and (iv) collaboration closely with, and sharing information among, local 
Environmental Protection Bureaus (EPBs) and provincial/country EPBs.  
 
93.  Sustainability. The pollution reduction, institutional, and financial benefits of the Project are 
expected to be sustainable, mainly because of the commitment at all levels of the Government to 
pollution control in river basins, particularly in the HRB. Several other factors also will contribute to 
project sustainability: (i) the actions already taken to establish wastewater companies that will 
operate on commercial basis, (ii) enactment of Tariff Regulation 1192 to ensure financial viability, 
(iii) financial covenants under the Project to ensure adequacy of tariffs, and (iv) provision of actions 
for institutional development and capacity building under the Project.

INSTITUTIONAL DEVELOPMENT COMPONENT 
 
1.  This  component  aims  to  increase  the  project  scope  from  merely  creating  assets  to 
effectively utilizing project-created assets in a sustainable manner. The implementing agencies (IA) 
for municipal wastewater management (MWM) and solid waste management (SWM) are in the 
early  stages  of  development.  As  such,  this  component  initially  establishes  and  strengthens 
institutional structures for the IAs. This component focuses on assisting the IAs to financial and 
operational independence,  efficiency,  and  sustainability;  as  well  as  on  strategic development, 
including private sector participation (PSP).  
 
A.  Analysis of Existing Implementing Agencies  
 
2.  The IAs’ financial management and institutional capacity were assessed using financial 
management  questionnaires,  which  cover  (i)  legal  structure;  (ii)  operational  structure;  (iii) 
processes; and (iv) financial, human resources, and MIS systems (Supplementary Appendix E). 
One MWM IA is registered as a company (though it is non-operational), while the other three 
MWMs IAs and three SWM IAs are to be registered before loan negotiations. Thus, the seven 
MWM  and  SWM  companies  require  organizational,  operational,  human  resources,  and  MIS 
systems; as well as corporate planning development.  
 
3.  The  MWM  and  SWM  value  chain  assets  (e.g.,  existing  sewerage  network,  and  new 
treatment  plants  and  landfills)  and  processes  are  industrial  wastewater  management  (IWM) 
subprojects for existing paper mills. These have company structures, operational procedures, 
financial management, and human resources development systems. 
 
4.  Local  project  management  offices  (LPMO)  have  been  set  up  to  monitor  the  project 
construction phase. The LPMOs are in the early stages of development, with only senior level staff 
assigned,  and  require  additional  staffing  and  training  in  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
procedures. While the Shandong Project Management Office (SPMO) has experience with the 
World Bank, it does not have any experience with implementing ADB loans. Thus, the SPMO 
needs strengthening during project implementation. 
 
B.  Proposed Institutional Strengthening Program 
 
5.  The Government’s “marketization reform policy” for the MWM and SWM sectors aims to 
increase efficiencies, reduce overhead costs, achieve true cost accounting, and improve service 
delivery.1 The policy advocates operational and managerial reforms to create sustainable MWM 
and SWM utilities through the promotion of market economy principles, PSP, and user fees that 
allow full cost recovery.2 Some large city utilities have been reformed into such market-oriented 
companies, promoting competition and commercialization of operations management. However, 
with few detailed guidelines for implementing the national policy, the fourth-tier local governments 
need assistance in implementing such reforms, especially in the SWM sector.  
 
6.  For the MWM and SWM subprojects, the goal of institutional development is to establish 
financially sustainable, operationally efficient, and managerially autonomous enterprises that can 
address long-term sector requirements. Discussions with the Government produced an agreement 
on corporatization, tariff reform, PSP, and accountability for operations and debt repayment to the 
enterprises for MWM and SWM sectors, which require short-term Government support. For the 
IWM subprojects, the focus is on the evaluation and implementation of PSP.

C.  Proposed PSP Strategy for MWM and SWM   
10.  ADB policy considers private sector development to be “crucial for the long-term, rapid 
economic  growth  of  a  country,  a  necessary  condition  for  sustained  poverty  reduction.” 3 
Recognizing  this  strategy,  the  Project  evaluated  the  introduction  of PSP  into  the  subprojects 
through extensive dialogue with the provincial and local governments, IAs, and public and private 
sector entities in the relevant sectors. As discussed in Supplementary Appendix A, the Project also 
researched past experiences and best practices.  
 
11.  Involving the private sector in the subprojects before construction is considered unrealistic, 
in light of the (i) small-scale capacities of subprojects; (ii) subproject locations in counties with low 
economic development; (iii) local government capacity constraints and limited experience with 
commercial market principles and practices, performance benchmarks, and regulatory and tariff 
structures; (iv) inefficient and fragmented nature of MWM and SWM operations without links to 
existing MWM sewerage networks, SWM collection, and transfer processes; and (v) likelihood that 
PSP in new asset construction only would lead to potential underinvestment in assets remaining 
outside the scope of an early PSP. Stakeholders have identified distortions where PSP was 
introduced without sufficient regard to sector reform. This has led to new assets operating under 
capacity and paying for fixed usage capacities per contract, poor performance monitoring, etc. 
 
12.  The  institutional  development  component,  therefore,  addresses  overall  sector  structure 
issues to implicitly catalyze sustainable PSP in the subprojects. Under this component, consultants 
will assist each MWM and SWM IA in evaluating potential options for PSP, leading to a viable PSP 
option  with  a  realistic  and  detailed  timetable  for  implementation.  PSP  options  that  can  be 
considered include (i) joint ventures between MWM IAs and private sector entities; (ii) development 
of private holding company structures for all MWM and/or SWM assets in the local areas, with PSP

D.  Proposed PSP Strategy for IWM: Quanlin and Changyuan Paper Mills 
 
15.  Pulp  and  paper  mills  are  large  contributors  to  environmental  pollution  in  the  People’s 
Republic of China’s (PRC). Thus, an effective environmental pollution control project is needed to 
address this issue. Noting that the non-wood pulping sector produces 44% of all industrial chemical 
oxygen demand (COD) pollutants, the World Bank has provided financial support for the Chengwu 
Paper Mills in Anhui Province.4 Quanlin Paper Mill’s discharges of 74,900 cubic meter per day 
(m3/day) of water to the river only meet current discharge standards of 300 milligram per liter (mg/l) 
COD through existing water treatment processes. Changyuan paper mill’s discharges of 20,000 
m3/day are at 400 mg/l COD levels. As both will be unable to comply with the new discharge 
standards of 120 mg/l COD levels by 2010, they require new and more effective water treatment 
systems.  
 
16.  Private  sector  funding  for  the  required  environmental  improvements  is  not  available, 
because commercial banks are unwilling to lend to projects that do not generate revenue, such as 
environmental  pollution  control  improvements.  Further,  in  the  absence  of  commercial  bank 
financing, the threat of closure will dampen potential interest from private sector entities at this 
stage. 
 
17.  If the required environmental measures are not implemented, the potential closure of the 
paper mills poses a major threat to the local economies. In addition to employees and their families, 
local farmers supplying straw are dependent on the paper mills for employment and income. 
Quanlin  employs  11,000  and  Changyuan  employs  1,500,  and  both  mills  support  large  pulp 
plantations  in  their  counties.  The  Project  will  fund  the  construction  of  effective  black  liquor 
treatment and wastewater treatment facilities at the two paper mills to (i) serve as environmental 
pollution control measures in addressing the existing externality, (ii) protect the local economy, and 
(iii)  catalyze  improvements  in  the  potential  of  the  enterprise  to  attract  PSP  following  its 
environmental upgrade.  
 
18.  The institutional development component explicitly includes introducing PSP in the two 
paper mills. Both companies have agreed to develop a time-bound strategy for PSP, which will

Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). The Kyoto Protocol sets targets for 
industrialized countries to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. These targets became 
legally binding on 16 February 2005. The CDM is intended as a “win-win” solution to reducing 
global GHG emissions.  
 
2.  The People’s Republic of China (PRC) ratified the UNFCCC on 5 January 1993 and the 
Kyoto Protocol on 30 August 2002. A designated national authority (DNA) has been established, 
which is co-chaired by the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) and the 
Ministry of Science and Technology (MOST). Provisional CDM regulations have been issued, and 
took effect in June 2004. With numerous projects under development, including three financed by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the PRC is expected to become one of the largest host 
countries of the CDM.1

The facility does not purchase the emission reductions (ER), known as carbon credits. Rather, it

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION OF SUBPROJECTS 
 
1.  The physical infrastructure components of the Project consist of (i) municipal wastewater 
management (MWM) in four subprojects, (ii) industrial wastewater management (IWM) in two 
subprojects, and (iii) solid waste management (SWM) in three subprojects. 
  
A.  Municipal Wastewater Management 
 
2.  Binzhou City. The service area is the Binzhou Economic Development Zone (BEDZ), 
which covers 86,000 people. BEDZ does not have a wastewater treatment plant (WWTP), and 
approximately 24,000 tons/day (t/d) of untreated wastewater is discharged into the Xisha River. 
This subproject consists of a 40,000 t/d secondary WWTP, a 30,000 t/d tertiary reuse water 
treatment plant, 65 kilometers (km) of sewer and 17 km of reuse water piping, and a 30,000 t/d 
capacity  lift  station.  This  WWTP  is  expected  to  have  sufficient  capacity  beyond  2015. 
Approximately 75% of the secondary treatment effluent will be purified further for industrial 
reuse. The remaining 10,000 t/d of secondary treatment effluent will be discharged to the Xisha 
River. Sludge generated from this WWTP will be dewatered and disposed of in a municipal 
landfill.  
 
3.  Gaotang County. The service area has about 150,000 people. Approximately 100,000 
t/d of untreated wastewater is discharged into the Majia River, a tributary in the Hai River Basin 
(HRB). This subproject includes (i) a 40,000 t/d secondary WWTP; (ii) a 40,000 t/d tertiary reuse 
water treatment plant; and (iii) 23 km of sewer, trunk sewer, and reuse water piping. The 
wastewater will undergo tertiary treatment for industrial reuse. The dewatered sludge will be 
used as fertilizer in Quanlin Paper Mill’s reed (a material for straw pulp) planting field.  
 
4.  Linqing City. The existing 30,000 t/d WWTP is sufficient for 25% of the wastewater 
generated in the service area, which has 280,000 people. The untreated and improperly treated 
wastewaters  are  discharged  directly  into  the  Weiyun  and  Xiaoyun  canals.  This  subproject 
includes (i) a 100,000 t/d secondary WWTP; (ii) a 50,000 t/d tertiary water reuse treatment plant; 
and (iii) 12 km of trunk sewer, reuse water piping, and treatment effluent discharge lines. Half of 
the effluent will be treated further for industrial reuse. Sludge generated from this WWTP will be 
disposed of in a new municipal landfill to be built under this Project. This proposed subproject is 
expected to reduce chemical oxygen demand (COD) loading in the HRB by more than 12,000 
tons per year. It also plays an important role in the South-to-North Water Diversion Project. 
 
5.  Shanghe County. The service area has 53,000 people, though the anticipated rapid 
growth will result in a threefold increase by the design year of 2015. As this area does not have 
a WWTP, the wastewater (15,000 t/d) is discharged into the Dehuixin and Shangzhong rivers. 
This proposed subproject includes a 40,000 t/d WWTP, 21 km of sewer, and two lift stations. 
Shanghe  County  does  not  have  a  sanitary  landfill.  In  the  short  term,  the  sludge  will  be 
composted, and then used as fertilizer in forestry.  
 
6.  With  an  average  COD  removal  rate  of  75%,  the  proposed  MWM  subprojects  are 
expected to reduce pollutants in the HRB. Water quality in HRB tributaries might not improve in 
the short term. However, with other HRB pollution control measures, long-term effects can be 
anticipated. This component will improve local residents’ quality of life and eliminate a source of 
pollution to the local groundwater.

B.  Industrial Wastewater Management  
 
7.  Dezhou Changyuan Paper Mill. Changyuan Paper Mill produces 65,000 tons per year 
of  straw  pulp.  With  the  mill’s  outdated  ammonia  cooking  method,  the  valuable  cooking 
chemicals cannot be reused. The current treatment method for the spent chemicals, called 
black liquor, is inefficient and ineffective. The WWTP for the midsection wastewater is unreliable, 
and would not meet the stringent standards after 2007. The black liquor and other wastewater 
that cannot be treated are stored in a large unlined storage lagoon or discharged without proper 
treatment. This lagoon is a major source of groundwater contamination. This subproject consists 
of (i) a 1,800 cubic meter per day (m3/day) black liquor recovery system with 200 t/d solid 
capacity and 43 t/d sodium hydroxide recovery; (ii) a 45,000 m3/day WWTP; and (iii) a 15,000 
m3/day process water recycling system. The proposed subproject is expected to eliminate a 
significant amount of pollutants (approximately 1,550 tons per year of COD) discharged into the 
HRB. Further, more efficient reuse of the black liquor saves energy and valuable materials. The 
wastewater  storage  lagoon  will  be  closed  within  6  months  after  the  start  of  project 
implementation. Proper closure of the lagoon will be a loan assurance, eliminating this long-term 
groundwater pollution source. 
 
8.  Gaotang Quanlin Paper Mill. Quanlin Paper Mill employs 11,000 people and produces 
350,000 tons per year of straw pulp. The black liquor generation rate (6,580 t/d) is projected to 
double when a new 300,000 ton-per-year wood pulp production line is added in 2007. The 
current black liquor pretreatment involves an outdated technology, which adds sulfuric acid to 
extract lignin to use as pellet fertilizer. This process destroys alkali that otherwise could be 
recovered, and consumes large quantities of sulfuric acid. The resulting wastewater contains 
extremely high concentrations of salts, which typical wastewater treatment processes cannot 
remove. Discharge of this treatment effluent into rivers would increase the salt contents in the 
receiving water bodies greatly, gradually rendering the river water unuseable for irrigation. The 
black liquor pretreatment (i.e., acidic lignin extraction) process requires high maintenance, and 
the extracted lignin cannot be reused readily. As such, Quanlin Paper Mill also has a large 
unlined storage lagoon to hold the unused lignin slurry. This lagoon is a major continuous 
source of groundwater contamination. This subproject consists of (i) an 11,470 m3/day black 
liquor recovery system with 2,440 t/d of solid capacity, (ii) a 536 t/d sodium hydroxide recovery, 
and  (iii)  a  485  t/d  lime  recovery  system  and  accessories.  This  subproject  is  expected  to 
eliminated a significant amount of regulated pollutants (292,200 tons per year of COD) and 
200,000 tons per year of unregulated inorganic salts. Recovery of alkali will save valuable 
resources, while greatly reducing the quantity of wastewater. Reducing the unregulated salts 
from  the  wastewater  treatment  effluent  has  invaluable  environmental  benefits.  The 
Implementing Agency (IA) has developed a plan to close the lignin storage lagoon properly by 
June 2006.

incorporated three crucial factors: (i) all significant point sources in the surrounding areas were 
to be controlled, (ii) all wastewater generators should face the same effluent charge, and (iii) the 
charge will approximate the marginal cost of processing wastewater at the municipal WWTP. 
According to standard economic theory, these principles can be considered sufficient to provide 
economic incentives for least-cost management of wastewater across all point sources.4

10.  The  established  environmental  improvement  plans  are  a  reasonable  approach  to 
(i) managing environmental protection and ambient water quality in SHRB, and (ii) planning for 
sustainable  urban  development  at  the  country/cities  in Shandong. The  Project  is  a  critical 
component of the established SHRB Plan, and represents a least-cost approach to achieving 
incremental improvements in environmental quality. Though limited in scope, it achieves public 
support through public participation in the planning process, stakeholder consultations, and 
surveys  undertaken  as  part  of  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance.  Of  the  800 
respondents  in  project  areas,  52%  ranked  MWM  and  SWM  improvements  as  priority 
investments. A majority of survey respondents were willing to pay directly for environmental 
facilities and services.  
 
C.  Evaluation of Individual Subprojects 
 
11.  In addition to being part of the HRB Plan, each subproject is economically justified on its 
own. Economic internal rates of return (EIRR) were estimated for MWM, industrial wastewater 
management  (IWM),  and  SWM  subprojects.  The  EIRRs  were  compared  with  economic 
opportunity cost of capital (EOCC), which was assumed to be 12%. Major economic benefits 
that were quantified for each component include the following:   
 
(i)  Municipal wastewater management: (a) tariff revenues paid by nonindustrial and 
industrial customers; (b) cost savings on environmental cleanup of canals and 
waterways  by  municipal  governments;  and  (c)  recycled  effluent  (100%  for 
Gaotang WWTP, 50% for Linqing WWTP, and 75% for Binzhou WWTP).   
(ii)  Industrial wastewater management: Direct economic benefits of adopting cleaner 
production  technology  include  cost  savings  from  (a)  direct  reduction  of 
conventional pollutants, such as chemical oxygen demand (COD), biochemical 
oxygen demand, and ammonia in their WWTPs; (b) reuse of steam energy and 
cooking  chemicals;  (c)  industrial  reuse  of  the  reclaimed  water,  sparing  good 
quality water for drinking or other domestic uses; and (d) preventing substantial 
amounts of unregulated salts from entering the HRB. 
(iii)  Solid waste management: (a) willingness to pay; and (b) cost savings on disease 
prevention/eradication, and environment cleanup. 
 
12.  Economic analysis was conducted over 25 years, including project construction in 2006 
and  completion  in  2011.  Economic  benefits  and  costs  are  denominated  in  domestic  price 
numeraire at constant 2005 prices. Foreign currency costs were converted to local currency 
costs using an exchange rate of CNY8.11 per $1 and adjusted based on purchasing power 
parity  assumption.  Project  tradable  components  were  adjusted  to  economic  prices  using 
shadow exchange rate factor of 1.013 and nontradable components valued at domestic market 
prices. Project costs and benefits were estimated on a without- and with-project basis. Transfer 
payments  were  excluded  in  the  valuation  of  cost  estimates  in  economic  prices.  Standard 
sensitivity tests, and additional tests for 1-year implementation delay and 20% increase in costs, 
were conducted. Sensitivity indicator (SI) and switching value (SV) were calculated.5

reuse. Water quality after treatment will meet discharge standards of pollutants for municipal 
wastewater. EIRRs are higher than EOCC of 12%, indicating that the MWM subprojects are
